title: 1¬† Introduction
text:
1.1 Summary
This week introduces basic concepts about remote sensing, physical principles, resolution of remote sensing data and data selection constraints, and familiarity with the software we will use.

1.1.1 Remote sensing
Remote sensing is the acquiring of information from a distance. NASA observes Earth and other planetary bodies via remote sensors on satellites and aircraft that detect and record reflected or emitted energy. Remote sensors, which provide a global perspective and a wealth of data about Earth systems, enable data-informed decision making based on the current and future state of our planet.  (Source: NASA. What is Remote Sensing? | Earthdata (nasa.gov))
 (Source: ESA. Copernicus Missions: Sentinel-1 images global landmasses, coastal zones and shipping routes with a C-band sensor)
Advantage of Remote Sensing

Data

Large area and time coverage.
Frequency of updates.
Easy data acquisition.
Provide useful information in various wavebands.
Repetitive coverage provides to monitor dynamic themes like agriculture.Stereo satellite data may be used for three-dimensional studies.

Data process

Free processing resources like GEE.

Policy

Policy decesions being made using Remote Sensing.


Disadvantage of Remote Sensing

Expensive for small areas.
Requires specialized training for analysis of images.
Aerial photos are costly if repetitive photos are required.



1.1.2 Overall view of working remote sensing system

The origin of electromagnetic energy (sun transmitter carried by the sensor).
Transmission of energy from the atmosphere of the earth.
Interaction of energy with the earth‚Äôs surface (reflectance/absorption/transmission) or self-emission.
Transmission of the reflectance/emitted energy to the remote sensor.
Detection of energy by the sensor, converting it into a photograph may be digital or analog.
Transmission/recording of the sensor output.
Pre-processing of the data and generation of the data product.
A collection of ground truth and other collateral information.
Data analysis and interpretation.
Various themes, or other applications.

 (Source:GeoLearn)


1.1.3 Sensor
Sensors, or instruments, aboard satellites and aircraft use the Sun as a source of illumination or provide their own source of illumination, measuring energy that is reflected back. Sensors that use natural energy from the Sun are called passive sensors; those that provide their own source of energy are called active sensors.

(Source: NASA. What is Remote Sensing? | Earthdata (nasa.gov))
Push Broom and Whisk Broom Sensors (originally taught in Chapter 3, I‚Äôve moved it here for ease of memory)
Whisk broom scanners, also sometimes referred to as spotlight or across track scanners, use a mirror to reflect light onto a single detector. The mirror moves back and forth, to collect measurements from one pixel in the image at a time.
Push broom scanners, also sometimes referred to as along track scanners, use a line of detectors arranged perpendicular to the flight direction of the spacecraft. As the spacecraft flies forward, the image is collected one line at a time, with all of the pixels in a line being measured simultaneously. One drawback of push broom sensors is that the detectors in the ‚Äúpush broom‚Äù can have varying sensitivity. If they are not perfectly calibrated, this can result in stripes in the data.
 (Source: RF Wireless World)


1.1.4 Electromagnetic
Electromagnetic energy, produced by the vibration of charged particles, travels in the form of waves through the atmosphere and the vacuum of space. These waves have different wavelengths (the distance from wave crest to wave crest) and frequencies.
 (Source: NASA. What is Remote Sensing? | Earthdata (nasa.gov))

EMR Interacting with Earth‚Äôs surface The EMR, on interaction with earth‚Äôs surface, experiences a number of changes in the magnitude, direction, wavelength, polarization and phase etc.

Absorption
Transmission

EMR Interacting with Atmospheric Before radiation used for remote sensing reaches the Earth‚Äôs surface it has to travel through some distance of the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. Particles and gases in the atmosphere can affect the incoming light and radiation. These effects are caused by the mechanisms of scattering and absorption.

Scattering

Rayleigh scattering
Mie scattering
Nonselective scattering

Absorption

Ozone





1.1.5 Data

There are four types of resolution that affet the quality and nature of the data a sensor collects: Spatial, Spectral, Temporal and Radiometric.
The select of data depends on these factors: Size of features, Date range, Revisit requirement, Spectral sensitivity, Cost.

 (Source: OneStopGIS)

title: 1¬† Introduction
text:
1.3 Reflection
This week‚Äôs teaching was interesting and fundamental, showing us the potential and applications of remote sensing technology. In China, as the spatial planning reform of the country progresses, planning authorities are placing increasing emphasis on remote sensing and 3D GIS technology.
For many years there has been a contradiction between land use planning and urban planning in China. With increased urbanisation, in particular, the conflict between arable land and urban built-up areas. In recent years, Chinese officials have undertaken a reform of the planning system, combining the two into one, called territorial spatial planning. Remote sensing has changed the way of territorial spatial planning, and its powerful data acquisition, analysis, prediction and management capabilities provide data, methods and management platforms to support territorial spatial planning.Remote sensing helps to achieve a refined and intelligent management of the whole cycle of territorial spatial planning.
Planning policies have been integrated to form a ‚Äúone map‚Äù for territorial spatial planning based on one map, which can be opened up in layers.
 (Source:Territorial spatial planning topic: Overview of the territorial spatial planning system)

title: 3¬† Remote sensing data
text:
3.1 Summary
Based on the understanding of the causes of distortion of remote sensing images, this week I learnt about the principles of pre-processing remote sensing image data, which are divided into correction and enhancement. I also learnt the basic concepts and specific steps of correction and enhancement by using R.

3.1.1 Corrections
When a remote sensing sensor receives electromagnetic radiation energy from a feature, the inconsistency between the measured value of the remote sensing sensor and the actual spectral emissivity of the feature, caused by the transmission of electromagnetic waves in the atmosphere and sensor measurements, is known as radiometric aberration, due to the effects of the characteristics of the remote sensing sensor itself, the lighting conditions of the feature (terrain effects and solar altitude angle effects) and atmospheric effects.
Geometric aberrations occur when the geometric position, shape, size, orientation and other features of features on the original image do not match the requirements for representation in the reference system.
Geometric and atmospheric corrections are pre-processing processes that address these two forms of aberration.
 (Source: Geolearn)

3.1.1.1 Geometric corrections
It is usually necessary to pre-process the remotely sensed data and remove the geometric distortion so that individual picture elements are in their proper planimetric (x, y) map locations.(Geolearn)
 (Example of Geometric corrections. Source: geography338.blog)

Causes of distortions

View angle (off-nadir)

Topography (e.g.¬†hills not flat ground)
Wind (if from a plane)
Rotation of the earth (from satellite)
Process of Geometric corrections

Coordinate transformation: Transformation of spatial position (image element coordinates)

Take the coordinates and model them to give geometric transformation coefficients
Plot these and try to minimise the RMSE - Jensen sets a RMSE value of 0.5  (Source: Abdul Basith)

Resample: recalculation of pixel grayscale values

Nearest Neighbor
Linear
Cubic
Cubic spline  (Source: Peter T. Bobrowsky)





3.1.1.2 Atmospheric correction
Atmospheric correction is a kind of Radiometric correction. The objective of atmospheric correction is to determine true surface reflectance values by removing atmospheric effects from satellite images (Themistocleous et al., 2008).
 (Example of Atmospheric correction. Source: NASA)

Causes of environmental attenuation

Atmospheric scattering
Topographic attenuation

Necessary and unnecessary atmospheric correction

Unnecessary

Classification of a single image
Independent classification of multi date imagery
Composite images (combining images)
Single dates or where training data extracted from all data

Necessary

Biophysical parameters needed (e.g.¬†temperature, leaf area index, NDVI)
E.g. .. .NDVI is used in the Africa Famine Early Warning System and Livestock Early Warning System
Using spectral signatures through time and space
Types of atmospheric correction

Relative atmospheric correction: Relative atmospheric correction (AC) methods avoid the evaluation of atmospheric components of any kind. They rely on the fact that, for one sensor channel, the relation between the radiances at Top Of Atmopshere and at ground level follows a linear trend for the variety of Earth features present in the image. This linear relation is in fact an approximation of reality, but for practical purposes it is precise enough when there are other, more important sources of error.(UT)
Absolute atmospheric correction: Absolute atmospheric correction (AC) methods require a description of the components in the atmospheric profile. The output of these methods is an image that matches the reflectance of the ground pixels with a maximum estimated error of 10%, provided that atmospheric profiling is adequate enough. This image can be used for flux quantifications, parameter evolution assessments, etc., as mentioned above. The advantage of these methods is that ground reflectance can be evaluated for any atmospheric condition, altitude and relative geometry between the Sun and satellite. The disadvantage is that the atmospheric profiling required for these methods is rarely available. To address this inconvenience, various absolute AC methods have been developed that have different requirements in relation to the atmospheric profiling data‚Äîand differences in the accuracy of the results. (UT)

Methods of atmospheric correction
empirical line method
image-based methods

histogram minimum method

regression method
radiative transfer models



3.1.1.3 Orthorectification correction / topographic correction
A subset of georectification, requires sensor geometry and an elevation model. Nd atmospheric correction happens before topographic correction. - georectification = giving coordinates to an image - orthorectification = removing distortions‚Ä¶ making the pixels viewed at nadir (straight down)
 (Example of Orthorectification correction. Source: esri)


3.1.1.4 Radiometric Calibration
Radiometric Calibration refers to the ability to convert the digital numbers recorded by satellite imaging systems into physical units. (SDSU)
 (Example of radiometric calibration. Source: Rodrigo et al., 2007)
 (Simplified schematic of atmospheric interference and the passage of electromagnetic radiation from the Sun to the satellite sensor. Source: Newcastle Univesrity)

Key terms
Digital number (DN): DN is a variable assigned to a pixel, usually in the form of a binary integer in the range of 0‚Äì255 (i.e.¬†a byte)
Radiance: Radiance is the variable directly measured by remote sensing instruments. Basically, you can think of radiance as how much light the instrument ‚Äúsees‚Äù from the object being observed.
Reflectance: Reflectance is a property of a material (e.g.¬†reflectance of grass is a property of grass)




3.1.2 Joining data sets / Enhancements

3.1.2.1 Joining data sets
This is termed ‚ÄúMosaicking‚Äù in remote sensing - but it‚Äôs not much different to merging in GIS.
Here is an example of a Landsat 8 band 753 colour-composite without seamless mosaicing:  And here is the same image with the use of the Mosaic With Feathering tool:  (Example of a Landsat 8 band 753 colour-composite without seamless mosaicking. Source: WhiteboxDev)


3.1.2.2 Enhancements
In terms of the object of action, contrast enhancement corresponds mainly to the image element, while filter enhancement takes into account the relationship between the image element and its neighbour elements.

Contrast Enhancement Image enhancement is the procedure of improving the quality and the information content of original data before processing.( Haldar, 2018)  ÔºàExample of contrast stretch, Source:Earth LabÔºâ
Ratio Normalized Burn Ratio (NBR) is used to identify burned areas and provide a measure of burn severity. It is calculated as a ratio between the NIR and SWIR values in traditional fashion. 


(Example of Normalized Burn Ratio. Source: USGS)

Filtering Low pass or low frequency (averages the surrounding pixels), High pass or high frequency - enhance local variations.
PCA To retain key information, reduce data volume and enhance or extract useful information through function transformation.
Principal Component
Transform multi-spectral data into uncorrelated and smaller dataset
Has most of the original information
Reduces future computation ‚Äúdimensionatliy reduction‚Äù
The first component will capture most of the variance within the dataset
In R this is from the RStoolbox packager asterPCA()
Texture Texture: spatial variation of gray values.
Fusion Image fusion is where data from multiple sensors / sources is fused together.

title: 4¬† Policy applications
text:
4.1 Summary
This week begins with an review to common applications of remote sensing data and an analysis of the powerful potential of remote sensing data from a policy perspective. Remo te sensing data is already characterised by high accuracy, 24/7 monitoring and rapid automated processing. In a wide range of fields such as disaster prevention, health, energy, climate, water, ecology and agriculture, remote sensing data is used to provide government decision makers with a comprehensive range of services from monitoring to assessment to improve the quality of human life worldwide.
These can be roughly divided into the areas of dynamic monitoring, feature identification, disaster prevention and mitigation, etc. (I categorise the example application from lecture according to my personal interests and add some examples from China.)
research on remote sensing in cities has focused on these two areas: (a) issues resulting from the expansion of urban environments, and (b) sustainable urban development.(Kadhim et al., 2016), In the area of sustainable development, my policy of choice is SDGs-1. Thinking about a developing country like China, how to monitor poor areas.

4.1.1 Dynamic monitoring

Urban expansion ‚Äì Landsat ([Zhang et al,. 2018(https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11769-018-0988-9)]).
Monitoring forests + illegal logging ‚ÄìLandsat (2000 to 2012).
Urban area mapping ‚Äì SAR, InSAR.
Multi-temporal land cover (or land use) mapping.
Urban green spaces ‚ÄìLandsat (medium res 17%),Sentinel, LiDAR, High spatial resolution, High + medium resolution‚Ä¶‚Ä¶
The power plant construction schedule and the environmental impact of the construction actions are monitored dynamically.
Changes in the area of a large number of water bodies.
Melting state of glaciers and snow.



4.1.2 Feature identification

Damage detection.
Illegal constructions detectionChen et al.2020. A example from Shenzhen is that since 2006, the dynamic monitoring work of satellite remote sensing within the ecological control line has been launched, using satellite remote sensing as an advanced technical means to dynamically monitor the city‚Äôs construction behaviour located within the basic ecological control line.(News: Remote Sensing Monitoring of Unauthorized Construction in Shenzhen)
Structured Outdoor Architecture Reconstruction Zhang et al.2020.



4.1.3 Disaster prevention and mitigation

Droughts ‚Äì Sentinel moisture index.
Forest fires ‚Äì Landsat TM 1984.
Earthquakes ‚Äì SAR, InSAR.
Urban flooding (lower backscatter coefficient) ‚Äì SAR,InSAR.
Air pollution and LULC ‚Äì Sentinel-3 Sea and Land Surface Temperature, Sentinel-5 Precursor Major Air Pollutants.

title: 4¬† Policy applications
text:
4.2 Application

4.2.1 SDGs-1

Case country :China
Policy

SDGs-1: NO POVERTY, 2015 Content: End poverty in all forms and dimensions by 2030.  (Source:UN)
Targeted poverty-alleviation strategy, 2014 Content: To apply scientific and effective procedures for precise identification, precise assistance and precise management of poverty alleviation targets in response to different poverty-stricken regional environments and the conditions of different poor farming households.  (Source: China Daily Global)

Overview Using socio-economic data and remote sensing data to assess the economic development of national poor counties based on predictive models. Firstly, in order to verify the rate of economic development in poor areas, the economic growth of more than five hundred poor counties is compared with the national growth rate; secondly, in order to study whether the gap between the rich and the poor has narrowed between regions, the trend of the change in economic differences between poor counties is compared. Providing an efficient and accurate means of assessing economic development on a large scale.

 (Geographical distribution of impoverished counties in China. Source:Heilig et al., 2006. Poverty Alleviation in China: A Lesson for the Developing World? )

Reference papers

Jean, Neal, et al., ‚ÄúCombining satellite imagery and machine learning to predict poverty.‚Äù
Yeh et al., ‚ÄúUsing publicly available satellite imagery and deep learning to understand economic well-being in Africa.‚Äù
Pokhriyal et al., ‚ÄúCombining disparate data sources for improved poverty prediction and mapping.‚Äù

Data

Google satellite imagery (from Google Earth)
Sentinel
LAI(Leaf Area Index)
Vector county Boundaries
Economic Development Data like GDP and TRSCG
Census data count by county

Time frame Targeted poverty-alleviation strategy was published in 2014, We can choose two time ranges, 2018-2013 and 2014-2022, before and after the policy was released.
Unit frame 529 national poverty counties.
Work frame

Using Google satellite imagery data, Sentinel, and LAI, to get extraction of data from farmland, built-up areas of towns, rivers and roads.
Using deep learning models to obtain MDI.
Comparing the economic changes in poor counties before and after the implementation of the Targeted poverty-alleviation strategy.

title: 5¬† Google Earth Engine
text:
5.1 Summary
This week is an introductory course to the Google Earth Engine (GEE), GEE Code Editor website, introducing GEE from its setup and functionality.
GEE is a powerful tool to help people understand the relationship between people and nature at a large scale, with all the Landsat, Sentinel and MODIS remote sensing data stored on GEE, and all the major remote sensing analysis algorithms integrated, and Google provides significant free computing power for users to analyse and process this data.
If remote sensing technology has made it possible to analyse the Earth, then the GEE remote sensing big data platform has made it feasible.
Here are some useful tutorials resources for beginners. You can also find more advanced tutorials recommended in the ‚öîÔ∏èPractical link.

GEE Guides
Welcome to Google Earth Engine
Gee-turtorials
Cloud-Based Remote Sensing with Google Earth Engine


5.1.1 Basics

(A great introduction from GEE team Nick Clinton)

5.1.1.1 What is Google Earth Engine (GEE)?
Earth Engine is a platform for scientific analysis and visualization of geospatial datasets, for academic, non-profit, business and government users.
Earth Engine hosts satellite imagery and stores it in a public data archive that includes historical earth images going back more than forty years. The images, ingested on a daily basis, are then made available for global-scale data mining.
Earth Engine also provides APIs and other tools to enable the analysis of large datasets.(Source:earthengine)
GEE‚Äôs philosophy includes that ‚ÄúOften it turns out to be more efficient to move the questions than to move the data.‚Äù, ‚ÄúAllowing scientists to focus more on scientific questions rather than spending their energy on downloading and managing massive amounts of data.‚Äù


5.1.1.2 Advantages of GEE

Over 900+ geospatial datasets to choose from, supporting planetary-scale data science.

Google Earth Engine‚Äôs data archive contains more than 40 years of historical imagery and scientific datasets, updated and expanded daily.It contains over 70 petabytes of geospatial datasets (including Landsat, Sentinel, and MODIS) that you can access quickly and easily in Earth Blox‚Äôs drag-and-drop, no-code interface. Not sure what dataset to use? No worries. We will help you find the right one for your analysis.(Source: Google Earth Engine,Google Earth Engine API)
 (Source: Forest loss in Sumatra‚Äôs Riau province, Indonesia, 2000-2012. Credit: Hansen, Potapov, Moore, Hancher et al., 2013)

Faster analyses with cloud processing.

Earth Engine runs on Google Cloud, giving you access to high-performance computing, even from a mobile device. And since it is cloud-based, you don‚Äôt need a high internet bandwidth as you won‚Äôt be downloading large files. This is especially useful for analysts working in countries with poor or unstable internet connectivity.


Upload your own data.

You can upload your own raster and vector data to the platform. You can also recommend datasets from the Javascript API Code Editor window by going the Help button on the top right and selecting Suggest a dataset.


5.1.1.3 disdvantages of GEE

There are several limitations on the use of datasets in GEE.

e.g., the data sets stored in GEE are not comprehensive (such as complex SAR is not included).

There is a limit to the amount of user-uploaded data that can be stored.
Requires JavaScript and Python coding skills.
Complex pricing.

Google provides two pricing options. The first is based on the consumption of Earth Engine resources (compute units and storage) and the second is a monthly subscription fee based on the number of user seats with consumption limits.
(The basics of GEE operation useful for me are covered in the opening mindmap and will not be summarised in text.)

title: 5¬† Google Earth Engine

5.2 Application
Useing ‚ÄúGoogle Earth Engine‚Äù as keywords to retrieve relevant articles and review articles from the Web of Science WoS core collection, including the SCIE (Science Citation Index Expanded) and SSCI (Social Sciences Citation Index), dated up to January 2021. After screening, 565 articles related to ‚ÄúGoogle Earth Engine‚Äù were obtained.(Source:Application of Google Earth Engine)

Research disciplines in which GEE.

The research areas with more than 100 publications were environmental sciences and ecology (365), remote sensing (363), and imaging science and photographic technology (129). These three research areas alone accounted for 70% of the total.  (Source:Zhao et al., 2021. Progress and Trends in the Application of Google Earth and Google Earth Engine)

Keywords related to GEE

It can be seen that the most frequently occurring keywords include ‚ÄúWater‚Äù, ‚ÄúHigh Resolution‚Äù, ‚ÄúManagement‚Äù, ‚ÄúRandom Forest‚Äù, ‚ÄúAlgorithm‚Äù, ‚ÄúCloud Platform‚Äù, and ‚ÄúModel‚Äù.  (Source:Zhao et al., 2021. Progress and Trends in the Application of Google Earth and Google Earth Engine)

title: 5¬† Google Earth Engine
text:
5.3 Reflection
Through its two values: cloud platform and super computing power, GEE enables the analysis of remote sensing data from complex to simple, from regional to global, from short time to long time series, so that in the future the processing and mining of remote sensing big data can be done not only by professional remote sensing people, but also by environmentalists, economists, sociologists and even ordinary people from the earth observation data of human beings for nearly half a century.
With the help of ChatGPT, the code barrier will no longer exist. The future of remote sensing is not only for professional remote sensing people, but also for environmentalists, economists, sociologists and even ordinary people to analyse global problems and help find solutions from the Earth observation data of the last half century.Reminds me of GOOGLE‚ÄôS MISSION STATEMENT ‚ÄúOur mission is to organise the world‚Äôs information and make it universally accessible and useful.‚Äù
